creator: grenoml@yahoo.com
text:
After upgrading to 4.1.9 (xml-cocoon2_20020902161948) from 4.0.3 some of my 
context entries refuse to run now.  I can run the manager, the admin directory 
is empty (was this overlooked?) so it doesn't run, the examples run, any of my 
contexts below D:\InetPub\wwwroot will run, but those that are located at other 
areas of my filesystem such as under D:\Projects\xxxxx refuse to run.  All 
these were working fine under 4.0.3. Also, when I drop WAR files into the 
Tomcat /webapps folder nothing happens.  I try accessing from the browser and 
they never get installed.  I downloaded Cocoon and built it and same thing.  
The Cocoon WAR never runs.  I've tried starting it from the manager and same 
thing - nothing.

Here's how my entries look in server.xml:
   <Context path="/jsp" docBase="D:\InetPub\wwwroot\jsp" debug="0" 
reloadable="true" /> 
   <Context path="/test" docBase="D:\InetPub\wwwroot\webapps" debug="0" 
reloadable="true" /> 
  <Context path="/jboss" docBase="D:\Projects\TomcatJBoss" debug="0" 
reloadable="true" /> 
  <Context path="/bonus" docBase="D:\Projects\Bonus" debug="0" 
reloadable="true">

I have a similar configuration which works fine. At least indicate what are the
errors you're getting. If Tomcat is properly installed, the admin webapp will be
there, and will run fine.

Please do a clean installation of TC 4.1, and then modify server.xml to add your
contexts. Do not attempt to use server.xml from Tomcat 4.0.x.
creator: remm@apache.org
grenoml@yahoo.com
text:
Sorry for posting the coccoon ver. for Tomcat.  Should have been (jakarta-
tomcat-4.1.9).  As far as server.xml, I was very careful to cut and paste my 
entries from the old server.xml into the new server.xml.  When I try to access 
the manager link on the Tomcat webcome page it shows as /manager/html and the 
admin link shows as /admin.  Would this have any bearing on why I get a 404 on 
admin?  I tried adding /html behind /admin in the URL but it didn't help.  I 
checked and yes all the files for admin are there, but under /server/webapps 
just like manager.  The entry in admin.xml looks ok and is redirecting 
to ../server/webapps/admin similar to manager so I'm confused as to what is 
causing this particular problem.  The install was to a new directory and not on 
top of the previous install so everything should be there.  Nothing was used 
from the previous install and after comparing to the tar file no files are 
missing.  I am using IIS and the ISAPI Jakarta Redirector from 4.0.3 but on 
install I did not allow it to overwrite any of the 4.1.9 jars and it seems to 
be working just fine.  Would there be any issue there?  As I stated previously 
only some of my contexts are working and these I tested on 8080 which shouldn't 
bring the redirector into the picture.  Except for some of my contexts and the 
fact that WAR files don't run when you drop them into /webapps everything else 
seems to be working just fine.  I spent a lot of time making sure that I 
installed this release properly and if there is any settings that need checked 
please advise.

creator: grenoml@yahoo.com
text:

creator: grenoml@yahoo.com
grenoml@yahoo.com
text:
OK, reading some recent bugs I came across 12140 from fmgomes.  fmgomes, thanks 
for your post.  I also put a 'temp' dir under %CATALINA_HOME% and that cleared 
up some of the problems I was seeing: the admin console now works, and WAR 
files now run.  However, I still have the problem of not being able to access 
some of my contexts.  I cannot access these at all on 80 - I received a page 
not found error (so is this some incompatibility with the ISAPI Jakarta 
Redirector?), and on 8080 I get 500 errors like this:

org.apache.jasper.JasperException: Connection refused: connect
	at org.apache.jasper.servlet.JspServletWrapper.service
(JspServletWrapper.java:246)
	at org.apache.jasper.servlet.JspServlet.serviceJspFile
(JspServlet.java:289)
	at org.apache.jasper.servlet.JspServlet.service(JspServlet.java:240)
	at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:853)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter
(ApplicationFilterChain.java:247)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter
(ApplicationFilterChain.java:193)
	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardWrapperValve.invoke
(StandardWrapperValve.java:260)
	at 
org.apache.catalina.core.StandardPipeline$StandardPipelineValveContext.invokeNex
t(StandardPipeline.java:643)

You need to create a "temp" directory.
The binary distribution includes one, and it will be created, unless you use the
.tar.gz distribution (which is for Unix only).
Windows users should try to use the .exe installer. Yes it works good, don't be
afraid :)
creator: remm@apache.org

text:
If the 'temp' directory is required for Tomcat 4.1.x versions to function 
properly then it should have been included in all distributions.  It was not 
required with earlier versions and people aren't going to know that they should 
create it.  The resulting errors don't readily lead you to know that the lack 
of a 'temp' directory is the problem.
creator: grenoml@yahoo.com
